data.source: Secondary analysis of the ELEMENT study (Assessment of Reading and Mathematics Development Study) including standardized tests and student/parent questionnaires
data.wave_or_subset: Sixth grade elementary school sample from ELEMENT; English Cloze test; German reading test; cognitive test administered in 4th grade
data.sample_size: N = 2835 students nested in 134 elementary school classes
data.notes: Sample from a major European city; identification of bilingual groups via reported home language from parents (student report used if parent data missing); 111 students lacked language information; multiple imputation (5 datasets) to handle missing data; analyses combined across imputations; nested structure accounted for (type = complex); achievement measures scaled with one-parameter IRT in ConQuest using WLEs (English M = 100, SD = 20).

method.description: The study conducted secondary analyses of a representative sixth-grade sample from the ELEMENT study to examine whether speaking a minority language at home, in addition to the school instructional language (German), is associated with higher achievement in English as a foreign language. English achievement was measured with a Cloze test scaled via IRT. Bilingualism was operationalized using reported home language, and bilingual subgroups were formed (Arabic-German, Chinese-German, Polish-German, Turkish-German, and heterogeneous ‘other’). The analyses controlled for general cognitive abilities, age, gender, socio-economic status (HISEI), parental education, cultural capital (books at home), and German reading proficiency. Missing data were handled via multiple imputation, and clustering at the class level was accounted for in regression models.
steps: Define monolingual and bilingual group membership based on reported regular use of a non-German home language; create specific bilingual language groups and a heterogeneous group.

Measure outcomes and predictors: English achievement via Cloze test (IRT WLE), German reading via standardized test (IRT scaled), general cognitive abilities via CFT 4-12R subtests (administered in 4th grade), and collect background variables (age, gender, HISEI, parental education, books at home).
Handle missing data using multiple imputation (5 datasets) based on a background model including individual- and classroom-level variables.
Conduct descriptive statistics for groups using the first imputed dataset with Bonferroni adjustments.

Estimate multiple regression models (Mplus, type = complex) predicting English achievement from: (a) bilingual status; (b) bilingual status by German proficiency levels; (c) bilingual language group dummies; sequentially add controls (cognitive abilities, age, gender, HISEI, parental education, cultural capital), and finally add German reading proficiency.
Pool results across imputed datasets and interpret coefficients, explained variance, and group differences.
method.models: Multiple linear regression models with dummy variables for bilingual status and specific bilingual language groups; models adjusted for covariates (general cognitive abilities, age, gender, HISEI, parental education, cultural capital) and, in final models, German reading proficiency; clustering at class level accounted for (type = complex); results combined across multiple imputations.
method.outcome_variable: English language achievement (Cloze test, IRT WLE, scaled to M = 100, SD = 20)
method.independent_variables: Bilingual status (bilingual vs monolingual); bilingual language group dummies (Arabic-German, Chinese-German, Polish-German, Turkish-German, other bilingual); German reading proficiency; bilingual-by-German proficiency levels (for subgroup analyses).
method.control_variables: General cognitive abilities (CFT 4-12R), age, gender, socio-economic status (HISEI), parental education, cultural capital (number of books at home).
method.tools_software: Mplus 5.21 (type = complex; type = imputation); ConQuest for IRT scaling; CFT 4-12R for cognitive ability testing.

results.summary: Controlling for socio-demographic and cognitive factors, speaking a minority language at home (bilingualism) was positively associated with English foreign language achievement. The advantage varied across bilingual groups: Chinese-German and Polish-German students showed clear benefits, the heterogeneous bilingual group also benefited, Turkish-German showed advantages when German reading proficiency was controlled, and Arabic-German performed similarly to monolinguals after controls. Proficiency in the instructional language (German) was the strongest predictor of English achievement; adding German proficiency substantially increased explained variance.
